Computer Science GACE
Computer Science Endorsement

The program shall prepare candidates who demonstrate computational thinking skills to formalize a problem and express its solution in a way that computers (human and machine) can effectively carry out as indicated by the following:

The program shall prepare candidates who demonstrate knowledge of and ability for applying computational thinking skills including decomposition, abstraction, and pattern recognition in problem solving;
The program shall prepare candidates who demonstrate skills in devising algorithms for solving computational problems and checking for the correctness of the algorithms
The program shall prepare candidates who demonstrate understanding of limitations of computing
The program shall prepare candidates who perform activities demonstrating applications of computational thinking skills
The program shall prepare candidates who demonstrate proficiency in at least one third-generation programming language such as Java, Python, C, or C++, as indicated by the following
The program shall prepare candidates who demonstrate knowledge of and skill regarding the syntax and semantics of a third-generation programming language, its control structures, and its data types
The program shall prepare candidates who demonstrate knowledge of and skill regarding common abstraction mechanisms including functions, data structures, and application programming interfaces (APIs)
The program shall prepare candidates who demonstrate knowledge of and skill in implementing algorithms into robust programs and testing and debugging these programs for correctness
The program shall prepare candidates who perform laboratory-based activities that demonstrate programming concepts proficiency in a third-generation programming language
The program shall prepare candidates who can document a program so that others can understand its design and implementation
The program shall prepare candidates who demonstrate proficiency in basic computer system components and organization as indicated by the following

The program shall prepare candidates who demonstrate knowledge of how data are represented on a computer including bits, bytes, words and binary, and both octal and hexadecimal number systems as well as conversions among them
The program shall prepare candidates who demonstrate knowledge of main components of a computer system including CPU, OS, Memory, I/O devices, and peripherals
The program shall prepare candidates who demonstrate knowledge of various types of storage options in a computing environment including hard drive, cloud storage, flash drives, DVDs

The program shall prepare candidates who demonstrate knowledge and understanding of how components of a computer system work together to produce programs and applications to solve computational problems
The program shall prepare candidates who demonstrate proficiency in fundamental principles of computer networks and the Internet as indicated by the following
The program shall prepare candidates who demonstrate knowledge of network components including hardware and software
The program shall prepare candidates who can explain how network topologies and protocols enable users, devices, and systems to communicate and collaborate with each other
The program shall prepare candidates who can examine the factors such as bandwidth, latency, and server capability that impact network functionality

The program shall prepare candidates who can explain the abstractions in the Internet and how the Internet functions including the assignment of IP addresses, routing, the domain name system (DNS), and the use of protocols

The program shall prepare candidates who can explain the characteristics of the Internet and the systems built on it including redundancy, fault tolerance, hierarchy in IP addressing scheme, hierarchy in the DNS and open standards, and the influence of these characteristics on the systems

The program shall prepare candidates who demonstrate proficiency in effectively and responsibly using computer applications to create digital artifacts, analyze data, model and simulate phenomena suggested by research and/or data as indicated by the following
The program shall prepare candidates who can effectively use computer applications to create digital artifacts such as audio, video, animation, presentation, and websites
The program shall prepare candidates who can extract information from data to discover, explain, and visualize connections or trends
The program shall prepare candidates who can create models and simulations to help formulate, test and refine hypotheses
The program shall prepare candidates who can form a model from a hypothesis generated from research and run a simulation to collect and analyze data to test that hypothesis
The program shall prepare candidates to use industry best practices in application development

The program shall prepare candidates who demonstrate proficiency and understanding of security, privacy, and safety concerns in computer systems, networks, and applications as indicated by the following
The program shall prepare candidates who can describe main tenets of information security including confidentiality, integrity, availability, authentication, and nonrepudiation
The program shall prepare candidates who can explain fundamental design principles

The program shall prepare candidates who can describe types of threats and vulnerabilities to computer systems and the appropriate incident response and handling as well as imaging and backup procedures
The program shall prepare candidates who can describe common network vulnerabilities (cyberattacks, identity theft, privacy) and their associated responses

The program shall prepare candidates who can identify safe, secure, and ethical digital behavior; use effective strategies to evaluate the quality, credibility, and validity of websites; and understand the current and future implications of careless digital decisions
The program shall prepare candidates to educate students on their role in the prevention of cyber- bullying and to take an active role in building positive online communities
The program shall prepare candidates to provide students with the ability to use effective search strategies to evaluate the quality, credibility, and validity of websites

The program shall prepare candidates who plan, organize, deliver, and evaluate instruction that effectively utilizes current technology for teaching computational thinking principles, computer programming and its applications as indicated in the following

The program shall prepare candidates who identify resources, strategies, activities, and manipulatives appropriate to teaching computer science including related curricular areas, professional teacher and student organizations, and careers
The program shall prepare candidates who know how to plan and implement instruction that allows students to use computer science in problem-solving and decision-making situations
The program shall prepare candidates who know how to plan and implement instruction using a wide range of instructional strategies for individuals and groups for a diverse student population
The program shall prepare candidates who create and implement multiple forms of assessment and use resulting data to gauge student progress and adjust instruction accordingly

The program shall prepare candidates to prepare students for the emerging technologies and educate them to become responsible digital citizens with safe, secure, ethical and professional digital behavior

The program shall prepare candidates to positively impact the achievement and attainment of underrepresented populations by incorporating instructional strategies to increase their students’ intentions to continue advanced studies in computer science
The program shall prepare candidates who work with business and industry leaders in establishing school/business partnerships and advisory committees and operate student organizations as appropriate.

Demonstrate an understanding of the mathematical concepts, logic, and syntax of

Compare and contrast game creation tools including scripting languages, extensibility,

Plan and layout the steps needed to execute a team project, from skills to

Identify potential safety hazards and take preventive action to maintain a safe and environmentally clean work environment.

Identify potential hazards and implement proper safety procedures, including precautions

Display good communication skills and professionalism while working with customers.

Clarify customer statements by asking pertinent questions related to expected job
performance using language customer can understand.

users and society.

applications for engaging the user

Recognize that technology provides the opportunity to enhance relevance, increase confidence, offer authentic choice, and produce positive impacts in learning.

en-us: (Clarifying statement: This is a general statement and should not be taught in isolation from the other standards.)

competencyText.en-us: Recognize the letters, numbers, and basic functions of a keyboard, touchpad/trackpad, mouse, and other input devices.
Use digital tools (e.g. computers, tablets, cameras, software, 3D printers, etc.…)  to build knowledge, produce creative artifacts, and make meaningful learning experiences for themselves and others.
Use the letters, numbers, and basic functions of the keyboard effectively (shift, space, tab, enter/return).
Identify and use the home row of the keyboard effectively.
Build (use, modify and/or create) collections of digital images and words to communicate learning using a variety of media types.
Analyze collections of digital images and words for how well each collection communicates learning.
Identify a problem of interest to the learner and create a solution using digital tools.
Identify personal information, understand the need to keep it private, and engage in activities for keeping personal information private.
Identify the rights, responsibilities, and opportunities of living, learning, and working in an interconnected society and model behaviors that are safe, legal, and ethical.

en-us: (Clarifying statement: For example, students can draw a “selfie” and analyze how others might make assumptions based on what they see. Given that feedback, students can revise their portrait.)

competencyText.en-us: Participate in systems for keeping personal information private and protected (for example: passwords, biometric sensors).
Understand shared information on the Internet can be permanent.
Recognize and avoid harmful behaviors in online environments (e.g. viruses, in-app purchases, cyber-bullying, etc).
Follow safety rules and exhibit responsibility when using a device.
Create an artifact that shows the use of positive safe behavior when using technology.
Recognize work that is created by others.
Recognize that credit is given for the work of others found online.
Create an artifact that demonstrates a positive personal digital identity.
Understand that a model is used for developing and testing ideas for a diverse range of users
Use the Design Process (use, modify, create) with a variety of tools to identify and solve problems by creating new, modified, or imaginative solutions.

en-us: (Clarifying statement: Types of tools that could be used include, but are limited to, photo editing, sound recording, and programming languages like Blockly.)

competencyText.en-us: Modify an existing model for a specific purpose or for a specific group of users.
Create and test a model and analyze it from the perspective of an end user.
Recognize that innovation in technology meets a range of needs (3D printing, coding, robotics, drones, etc.).
Understand that innovation follows a process such as system life cycle, engineering design (use, modify, create) or design thinking (empathize, define, ideate, prototype and test).
Recognize that problems can be broken down into smaller parts in order to create a solution. Vocabulary Term: Decompose (to break down)
Develop and employ Computational Thinking strategies (break-down, find patterns, and create algorithms) to identify and solve problems.

en-us: (Clarifying statement: Associating these vocabulary terms with plugged or unplugged instructional activities will build familiarity with the language of computational thinking to prepare students for in-depth application in later grades.)

competencyText.en-us: Identify patterns
Create and use Algorithms (a set of step-by-step instructions) to complete a task.
Use Algorithms (a set of step-by-step instructions) to construct programs (using a block-based programming language or unplugged activities) that accomplish a task as a means of creative expression.
Identify multiple ways solutions can be applied to solve problems. Vocabulary Term: Abstraction
Analyze and debug (identify and fix) with or without a computing device.
Understand that technology is everywhere and changes our lives.
Understand how people can use technology.

en-us: (Clarifying statement: Appropriate hardware and software for this age group could include robots, block-based programming platforms such as Scratch, and digital pictures, audio, and animation.)

competencyText.en-us: Understand that there is a connection between people and devices.
Practice using and identifying basic hardware and software using accurate terminology.
Create simple artifacts using a computing device.
Identify that technological innovation changes how people live and work.
Understand that when you are on a networked device you are connected to other people.
Practice using a variety of computing hardware and software to achieve personal learning goals.
Identify and describe solutions to simple hardware and software problems (ex. volume control).
Describe how technology can impact an individual’s life positively and negatively.
Use devices appropriately
Choose and use appropriate hardware and software tools for a given purpose using accurate terminology.
Create a variety of artifacts.
Use digital tools to creatively share and express ideas.

en-us: (Clarifying statement: Examples of artifacts could include digital images, audio recordings, and storyboards.)

competencyText.en-us: Exchange information or ideas clearly and creatively using digital tools while considering audience and intended purpose.
Present information using a digital device.
Create artifacts for specific purposes that give and receive feedback.
Understand that answers to questions can be found through research from a variety of sources.
Select appropriate sources to conduct authentic research to produce a relevant and credible product.

en-us: (Clarifying statement: In this grade band, research skills should be developed in the context of simple problems, such as how seeds grow in a school garden or how to clean a bedroom. Students can find information from two or three sources. Evaluating the accuracy of sources will be taught in later grade levels.)

competencyText.en-us: Understand that resources on the Internet vary in quality and are found in a variety of places so care is needed in selection.
Understand there is an appropriate place to find information to research the answer to a question.
Progress from using a teacher developed list of resources, to selecting resources independently.
Select digital and analog resources, explain why a source was selected, and describe why it was the best source.
Collect and organize data.
Create a product of research collaboratively or independently. (e.g., table of data, writing assignment, collection of resources).
Create and share a research project reflecting and crediting a variety of quality resources.
Identify technology (hardware and software) that allows collaboration with others.
Use digital tools to collaborate with others both locally and globally.

en-us: (Clarifying statement: Examples of global interaction could include comments on Scratch projects from other students around the world.)

competencyText.en-us: Use digital tools to connect with individuals from different backgrounds and cultures.
Understand features of online environments
Participate in various roles on a team to work on a common goal and create an inclusive environment.
Participate in an online collaborative learning environment.
Create original works or responsibly repurpose or remix digital resources into new creations.
Select and use the most appropriate platform, tool, style, format and digital media to clearly and creatively express thoughts, messages, goals, or positions.

en-us: (Clarifying statements: An example may include creating a digital portfolio for students’ artwork.)

competencyText.en-us: Communicate complex ideas clearly and effectively by creating or using a variety of digital objects.
Publish or present content that customizes the message and medium for their intended audiences.
Explore local and global issues using digital tools to connect with learners from a variety of backgrounds and cultures
Use digital tools to expand personal viewpoints and enrich learning by collaborating effectively both locally and globally.

en-us: (Clarifying statement: Examples of global interactions could include making suggestions for improvement of Scratch or Khan Academy coding projects from students around the world.)

competencyText.en-us: Plan the development of a program by including others' viewpoints and considering user preferences.
Take on varying roles, with teacher guidance, when collaborating with peers during the design, implementation, and review stages of program development.
Describe choices made during program development using code comments, presentations, and demonstrations.
Seek diverse perspectives for the purpose of improving computational artifacts.
Understand and use effective research strategies to locate information and other resources.
Gather, evaluate, and organize quality information from multiple sources.
Evaluate the accuracy, perspective, credibility and relevance of information, media, data, or other resources.
Use information from multiple sources to identify real-world issues and create solutions.
Describe how internal and external parts of computing devices function to form a system.
Identify the features of current technologies and use that knowledge to understand emerging technologies.

en-us: (Clarifying statement: An example could include teaching about functional differences between a monitor and computer keyboard and how they work together in a computing system.)

competencyText.en-us: Model how computer hardware and software work together as a system to accomplish tasks.
Determine potential solutions to solve simple hardware and software problems using common troubleshooting strategies.
Develop and apply keyboarding skills, utilizing current technology.
Compare and contrast prior knowledge on current technologies with that of new or emerging technologies.
Develop, reflect on, and revise personal learning goals in collaboration with their peers.
Curate (analyze and evaluate) information from digital resources using a variety of tools and methods to create collections of artifacts that demonstrate meaningful connections or conclusions.
Curate (analyze and evaluate) a variety of resources and digital tools to construct knowledge and produce creative artifacts.

en-us: (Clarifying statement: Examples could include using search engines and collecting real-world information using interviews. Students can use different information sources to make connections and draw conclusions. The use of citations and reference lists are taught in upper grades.)

competencyText.en-us: Build knowledge by actively exploring real-world issues.
Explain why a real-world issue exists or was created and develop a possible solution.
Organize and present collected data visually to highlight relationships and support a claim.
Discuss real-world cybersecurity problems (e.g. viruses, phishing attacks, click bait, etc) and how personal information can be protected.
Identify the rights, responsibilities, and opportunities of living, learning, and working in an interconnected society and model behaviors that are safe, legal, and ethical.

en-us: (Clarifying statement: Examples could include cyber-bullying and the risks and benefits of online-only friendships. Specific cybersecurity and networking skills are taught in later grades.)

competencyText.en-us: Understand, demonstrate, and encourage respect for intellectual property of print and digital media.
Create and manage digital identity through positive, safe, and ethical online interactions.
Explore and practice a deliberate design process for generating ideas, testing theories, creating innovative artifacts, or solving authentic problems.
Use a variety of technologies within a design process to identify and solve problems by creating new, useful, or imaginative solutions.

en-us: (Clarifying statement: Examples could include designing solutions to community or classroom challenges. Design thinking begins with building empathy for those impacted by a problem and includes modeling and prototyping possible solutions.)

competencyText.en-us: Select, evaluate, and use appropriate digital tools to plan and manage a design process.
Modify, remix, or incorporate portions of an existing program into one's own work, to develop something new or add more advanced features.
Compare and refine multiple algorithms for the same task and determine which is the most appropriate.
Develop and employ strategies for understanding and solving problems in ways that use the power of technological methods to develop and test solutions.

en-us: (Clarifying statement: Students can work in a Blockly coding environment, such as Scratch, with well-defined problems.)

competencyText.en-us: Decompose (break down) problems into smaller, manageable subproblems to facilitate the program development process.
Test and debug (identify and fix errors) a program or algorithm to ensure it runs as intended.
Create programs that include sequences, events, loops, conditionals, and variables.
Discuss computing technologies that have changed the world, and express how those technologies influence, and are influenced by, cultural practices.
Understand the relationship between technology, lifelong learning, and the appropriate use of information.

en-us: (Clarifying statement: Examples of computing technologies may include the Internet, digital media, or robotics.)

competencyText.en-us: Identify and propose ways to improve usability of technology for diverse users.
Foundations of Interactive Design
Understand the difference between editing a shared document and suggesting edits (e.g. track changes).

Use technology resources to increase self-direction and self-regulation in learning, including for problem solving and collaboration (e.g., using the Internet to access online resources, edit documents collaboratively).
Empowered Learner
Use digital tools or platforms to organize, display, annotate, and/or share a curated collection.
Complete an individual project (e.g., research or design) using technology resources.
Understand that digital content is permanent and cannot be deleted.

Understand benefits and risks of digital citizenship and practices safe, responsible, legal, and ethical behavior while using technology tools and resources, especially related to personal information.
Digital Citizen
Explore computer science and computing-related careers.
Investigate a career that requires computing and technology.
Describe how computer science enhances other career fields.
Predict the role of computer science in future careers.
Articulate ideas responsibly by observing intellectual property rights and giving appropriate attribution.
Understand the pervasiveness and tradeoffs of computers and computing in daily life.
Find and adjust privacy settings for online accounts; discuss the positive and negative effects that social media can have on one's life.
Recognize how the overuse of technology can impact mental, physical, and emotional health.
Identify phishing emails, insecure websites (e.g., not https), and risky links when on the Internet; build a positive digital footprint (e.g., blog, website, social media).
Apply strategies for troubleshooting hardware and software problems that may occur during use.
Choose the correct settings for printing and troubleshoot common printing issues (printer not turned on, printer not connected).
Connect devices (including internet/WIFI and Bluetooth) and troubleshoot common connection issues (e.g., disrupted Internet connection, website that is not loading).
Manage and deploy software updates and troubleshoot simple software issues (i.e., look up solutions to issues).
Explore the relationship between computer hardware and software.
Develop a working vocabulary of embedded computing including digital, analog, events, microcontrollers, sensors, LED, switch, servo, cloud computing, and internet of things.
Investigate how software interacts with hardware in the boot process.
Analyze and explain how computers communicate information with simple hardware inputs and outputs.
Create a product that analyzes how simple computer hardware can be used to develop innovative new products that interact with the physical world.
Design a computer program that senses something in the real world and changes an output based on the input.
Investigate and identify the basic components of computers and networks.
Identify the basic components of the computer by disassembling and reassembling a demonstration model personal computer (can be done ‘virtually’ online if demo model is not available).

Demonstrate an understanding of key functional components (input devices, output devices, processor, operating system, software applications, memory, storage, wi-fi and/or ethernet ports, and IP addresses).
Demonstrate an understanding of the terms and units used to describe major hardware components (RAM, ROM, GHz, MHz, GB, MB, CD, DVD, RW).
Explain the interrelation of the operating system software, application software, and utility software, citing specific examples of each.

Develop a basic vocabulary of networks including the Internet, wired, wireless, cellular, wi-fi, messages, packets, connections, bandwidth, broadband, firewall, hacking, cybersecurity, encryption, local area network (LAN), wide area network (WAN), and OSI model.
Demonstrate an understanding of the fundamental concepts for how computers process programming commands (hex, binary language, sequence of commands, conditional structures, looping structures).
Investigate ways to differentiate networks and how they are used in business and industry.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Networks and the Internet

competencyText.en-us: Create diagrams to illustrate types of network topologies to include star, ring, bus, mesh, and hybrid.
Differentiate networks based on coverage area including local area network (LAN), wide area network (WAN), and personal area network (PAN)
Differentiate between different network mediums including Wi-fi, wired, satellite, and microwave.
Evaluate and provide a rationale for the levels of the Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) model.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Networks and the Internet

competencyText.en-us: Summarize from multiple sources the physical and digital aspects of computing networks.
Trace the layers required to transmit data from one node to another (the OSI model).
Construct and explain the basic functions of the OSI model.
Examine the basics of cybersecurity needs for business, government, and organizations.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Networks and the Internet

competencyText.en-us: List and define the elements of the confidentiality, integrity, and availability (CIA) triad.
Explain components of access control: Identification, Authentication, Authorization, Accountability, and Non-repudiation.
Identify the characteristics of strong vs. weak passwords in data and identity security.
List and describe the basic steps in security risk management.
Develop a logical argument for the importance of physical security.
Cite evidence regarding the principles of cybersecurity and basic mechanisms used for protecting data and resources.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Networks and the Internet

competencyText.en-us: Define the cybersecurity first principles of least privilege, minimization, abstraction, domain separation, process isolation, information hiding, layering, simplicity, modularity, and resource encapsulation.
Apply concepts related to the principles behind encryption, including the purpose of cryptography, hashing, and steganography.
Draw conclusions illustrating a basic understanding of internet protocol (IP) packets, ports and network transmission.
Summarize from multiple sources a basic understanding of anti-malware, firewalls, intrusion detection system/intrusion prevention system (IDS/IPS), and virtual private network (VPN).
Analyze and describe the characteristics of cybersecurity ethics, digital citizenship, and laws governing privacy.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Networks and the Internet

competencyText.en-us: Explain the differences between a white hat (ethical) hacker and a black hat (unethical) hacker.
Cite evidence regarding the practice of ethical digital decision-making, including plagiarism, copyright law, and software licensing types (freeware, public domain, shareware, etc.).
Summarize and provide examples regarding security and privacy laws and their impact on society, citing recent cases.
Analyze cyberbullying to include legal and social consequences.
Develop a set of guidelines to prevent cyberbullying.
Develop arguments for policy-driven and technology-driven security.
Discuss the benefits and risks of using password management systems and storing personal information online.
Understand how browser settings such as cookies collect data and track personal information.
Demonstrate an understanding of the credibility, bias, accuracy, relevance, age appropriateness, and comprehensiveness of electronic information sources.
Evaluate the accuracy, relevance, appropriateness, comprehensiveness, and biases that occur in electronic information sources.
Knowledge Constructor
Gather, manipulate, and analyze data using a variety of digital tools to identify solutions and make informed decisions.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Data and Analysis

competencyText.en-us: Gather data and calculate numerical equations using spreadsheet formulas and functions.
Use spreadsheet data to create tables, charts, and graphs.
Use spreadsheets and databases to make predictions, solve problems, and draw conclusions.
Traverse online environments using critical thinking to find valid sources of information.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Data and Analysis

competencyText.en-us: Analyze various ways to visually represent data.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Data and Analysis

competencyText.en-us: Interpret tables, charts, and graphs created by someone else.
Discuss design decisions in choosing between text, tables, charts, and graphs.
Discuss design decisions to make visualizations of data clear and concise.
Evaluate and discuss of the credibility, bias, accuracy, relevance, age appropriateness, and comprehensiveness of electronic information sources.
Apply strategies for determining the reliability of information found on the Internet.
Recognize that there may be multiple approaches to solving a problem.
Innovative Designer and Creator
Approach problem solving iteratively, using a cyclical process.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Innovative Designer and Creator

competencyText.en-us: Design, develop, debug and implement computer programs.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Innovative Designer and Creator

competencyText.en-us: Develop a working vocabulary of programming including flowcharting and/or storyboarding, coding, debugging, user interfaces, usability, variables, lists, loops, conditionals, programming language, events.
Utilize the design process to brainstorm, implement, test, and revise an idea
Cite evidence on how computers represent data and media (sounds, images, video, etc.).
Design a user interface and test with other users using a paper prototype.
Implement a simple algorithm in a computer program.
Develop an event driven program.
Create a program that accepts user and/or sensor input and stores the result in a variable.
Create a computer program that implements a loop.
Develop a program that makes a decision based on data or user input.
Debug a program with an error.
Develop a plan to create, design, and build a website with digital content to a specific target market.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Innovative Designer and Creator

competencyText.en-us: Identify the objectives (e.g., increase sales, promote new products, increase company awareness, target new customers) for the website’s target market.
Specify website requirements, including timeline and resources, and organize them into a requirements document.
Evaluate a variety of web design tools and development platforms using an evaluation instrument and choose the appropriate platform.
Design digital products that reveal a professional layout and look by applying design principles to produce professional quality digital products.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Innovative Designer and Creator

competencyText.en-us: Identify graphical elements and the appropriate use of elements on a web site.
Explore and apply color principles to digital products.
Establish a brand through consistent use of graphics, color, layout and text.
Analyze the look and layout of a website based on the first impression of content and page elements. Get feedback from independent people and incorporate where appropriate.
Create a single functional web page using a web development platform based on a design mockup and user requirements.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Innovative Designer and Creator

competencyText.en-us: Create and edit images and graphics for website publication.
Plan, produce, and edit digital audio for website publication.
Plan, produce, edit, and post a multimedia-rich video project to a website.
Plan, produce, and edit animations for website publication.
Develop and use a test plan to debug each new website version to ensure it runs as intended and meets the end-user requirements for a responsive site.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Innovative Designer and Creator

competencyText.en-us: Create a test and debug plan. Resolve issues and fix any errors that surface during the test and debug process.
Create an end user testing plan, get user feedback, and incorporate feedback into the final website.
Prepare website for publishing and promotion.
Develop a plan to create, design, and build a game with digital content for a specific target market.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Innovative Designer and Creator

competencyText.en-us: Explore various game types including role-playing games (RPG), real-time strategy (RTS), simulations, puzzles, educational, massively multiplayer online (MMO), and others.
Create a Game Design Document (GDD), which includes, characters, story, theme, and gameplay mechanics.
Develop a visual model of a game from the Game Design Document (GDD).

en-us: Conceptual Category: Innovative Designer and Creator

competencyText.en-us: Create storyboards from the GDD that demonstrate game progression and consistent use of a theme.
Use the GDD to design the wireframes and comprehensive layout for the user experience (UX).
Create a functional game, using a game development platform, based on the storyboards, wireframes, and comprehensive layout.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Innovative Designer and Creator

competencyText.en-us: Create game elements, backgrounds, and characters.
Use scripting languages to create desired game mechanics, and to control the environment, user interface (UI), and character behaviors.
Plan, produce, and edit graphics and animations for game publication.
Plan, produce, and edit digital audio for game publication.
Develop and use a test plan to debug use each time a version of the game is released to ensure it runs as intended and meets the end-user requirements.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Innovative Designer and Creator

competencyText.en-us: Create a test and debug plan. Resolve any issues and fix any errors that surface during the test and debug process.
Create an end user testing plan, get user feedback, and incorporate feedback into the final game.
Prepare final game for publishing prior to publishing to the target audience.
Create digital artifacts to address a current issue requiring resolution.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Innovative Designer and Creator

competencyText.en-us: Summarize ethical, privacy, and legal issues of a digital world using current case studies.
Collaborate as a team to develop an artifact that represents multiple perspectives regarding a global crisis.
Analyze and explain the functionality and suitability (or appropriateness) of a computational artifact.
Develop a program for creative expression or to satisfy personal curiosity which may have visual, audible, and/or tactile results.
Develop a program specifically with the goal of solving a problem, creating new knowledge, or helping people, organizations, or society.
Identify sub-problems to consider while addressing a larger problem.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Recognizing and Defining Computational

competencyText.en-us: Computational Thinker
Recognize when it is appropriate to solve a problem computationally; Make sense of computational problems and persevere in solving them.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Recognizing and Defining Computational

competencyText.en-us: Develop through application, logical observations relative to computational thinking procedures to analyze and solve problems current to everyday life.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Recognizing and Defining Computational

competencyText.en-us: Identify characteristics of computational thinking (decomposition, pattern recognition, algorithmic thinking and abstraction).
Explain issues and analyze routine hardware and software problems current to everyday life.
Apply troubleshooting concepts to issues regarding compatibility, data, and identity.
Describe ways to resolve operational problems caused by hardware errors.
Explain how technology can create ethical and legal issues in the business world and a technology-based society and how it can be used to solve & manage those issues.
Utilize computational thinking to solve problems.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Recognizing and Defining Computational

competencyText.en-us: Make observations and organize the concepts of modularity, including functions and methods, as it relates to programming code reusability and cloud computing in the software industry.

Develop a working vocabulary of computational thinking including sequences, algorithms, binary, pattern matching, decomposition, abstraction, parallelization, data, automation, data collection, data analysis, boolean, integer, branches (if...then...else), and iteration {loops (For, While)}.
Analyze the problem-solving process, the input-process-output-storage model of a computer, and how computers help humans solve problems.
Develop an algorithm to decompose a problem of a daily task.
Recognize when to use the same solution for multiple problems.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Recognizing and Defining Computational

competencyText.en-us: Evaluate the storage and representation of data; Analyze how data is collected with both computational and non-computational tools and processes.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Data and Information

competencyText.en-us: Discuss binary numbers, logic, sets, and functions and their application to computer science.
Explain that searches may be enhanced by using Boolean logic (e.g., using “not”, “or”, “and”).
Understand and use the basic steps in algorithmic problem solving in computing and other authentic applications.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Algorithms

competencyText.en-us: Select basic steps to solve algorithmic problems.
Evaluate basic steps of algorithmic problem solving to design solutions.
Solve algorithmic problems of increasing complexity.
Use and compare simple coding control structures (e.g., if-then, loops)

en-us: Conceptual Category: Programming

competencyText.en-us: Use a visual block-based and/or text-based programming language individually and collaboratively to solve problems of increasing complexity.
Create a program individually and collaboratively using a text-based programming. language; Identify variables and compare the types of data stored as variables.
Consider the purpose of computational artifacts for practical use, personal expression, and/or societal impact.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Creating Computational Artifacts

competencyText.en-us: Compare and contrast examples of high level and low-level programming languages.
Investigate the notion of hierarchy in computing including high level languages, translations, instruction sets, and logic circuits.
Develop problem solutions using a programming language, including all of the following: looping behavior, conditional statements, expressions, variables, and functions.
Test computational artifacts systematically by considering multiple scenarios and using test cases.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Testing and Refining Computational Artifacts

competencyText.en-us: Describe how humans and machines interact to accomplish tasks that cannot be accomplished by either alone.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Human-Computer Interaction

competencyText.en-us: Identify what distinguishes humans from machines focusing on human intelligence versus machine intelligence (e.g., robot motion, speech and language understanding, and computer vision); Explain why some tasks can be accomplished more easily by computers.

Describe ways in which computers use models of intelligent behavior (e.g., robot motion, speech and language understanding, and computer vision) and how they differ (e.g., emotional decision making versus logical decisions, common sense, literal versus abstract).
Design and demonstrate the use of a device (e.g., robot, e-textile) to accomplish a task, individually and collaboratively.
Use online resources to participate in collaborative activities for the purpose of developing solutions or products.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Collaborating Around Computing

competencyText.en-us: Creative Communicator
Improve teamwork and collaboration skills: providing useful feedback, integrating feedback, understanding, and accepting multiple perspectives.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Collaborating Around Computing

competencyText.en-us: Understand the difference between CC and BCC as well as Reply and Reply All and when to use each appropriately.
Collaborate productively and recognize the value of working with individuals of varying perspectives, skills, and backgrounds.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Collaborating Around Computing

competencyText.en-us: Set and implement equitable expectations and workloads when working in teams.
Demonstrate correct keyboarding techniques while increasing speed and maintaining accuracy.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Collaborating Around Computing

competencyText.en-us: Use productivity technology tools (e.g. word processing, spreadsheet, presentation software) for individual and collaborative writing, communication, and publishing activities.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Collaborating Around Computing

competencyText.en-us: Recognize that equitable access to computing benefits society as a whole.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Fostering an Inclusive Computing Culture

competencyText.en-us: Global Collaborator
Consider others’ perspectives as well as one’s own perspective when developing computational solutions.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Fostering an Inclusive Computing Cult

competencyText.en-us: Consider the needs of a variety of end users regarding accessibility and usability.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Fostering an Inclusive Computing Cult

competencyText.en-us: Use software applications to collaborate and create authentic products.

en-us: Conceptual Category: Fostering an Inclusive Computing Cult

competencyText.en-us: Identify and utilize the appropriate software application for productivity.
Use various applications in a professional manner to share and communicate with peers and teachers.
Share documents created using word processing, presentation, and spreadsheet software.
Create original works using software applications in a collaborative manner.
Collaborate in small groups to create and edit online documents in real time.
Identify and use appropriate file sharing strategies (e.g., copy and paste, links, posts, and attachments).
Demonstrate employability skills required by business and industry.
Communicate effectively through writing, speaking, listening, reading, and interpersonal abilities.

Demonstrate creativity by asking challenging questions and applying innovative procedures and
methods.

Exhibit critical thinking and problem solving skills to locate, analyze and apply information in
career planning and employment situations.

Model work readiness traits required for success in the workplace including integrity, honesty,
accountability, punctuality, time management, and respect for diversity.

Apply the appropriate skill sets to be productive in a changing, technological, diverse workplace
to be able to work independently and apply team work skills.
Present a professional image through appearance, behavior and language.

Explore how related student organizations are integral parts of career and technology
education courses through leadership development, school and community service
projects, entrepreneurship development, and competitive events.
Explain the goals, mission and objectives of Future Business Leaders of America.

Explore the impact and opportunities a student organization (FBLA) can develop to bring
business and education together in a positive working relationship through innovative
leadership and career development programs.

Explore the local, state, and national opportunities available to students through
participation in related student organization (FBLA) including but not limited to
conferences, competitions, community service, philanthropy, and other FBLA activities.

Explain how participation in career and technology education student organizations can
promote lifelong responsibility for community service and professional development.

Explore the competitive events related to the content of this course and the required
competencies, skills, and knowledge for each related event for individual, team, and
chapter competitions.

Define key terms in site development: cloud computing, versions of HTML, CSS,
design consistency, deprecated tags, wire framing/layout design, hyperlinks.

Develop a logical argument for using cloud computing and the various web hosting
platforms for business and personal use.
Describe and illustrate different versions of HTML and the development of HTML.

Describe the phases of web development (life cycle) and provide specific tasks for
each phase.
Use flowcharts/storyboards to design a web site.

Identify essential web site navigation issues that help ensure site usability
(consistency, intuitive text/icons, and breadcrumbs).

Describe ethical, government, and accessibility standards & W3C standards
(readability, usability, browser compatibility, and copyright issues related to use of
digital media).

Identify technologies available to enhance the user's experience, including
programming languages and multimedia technologies.

Identify basic HTML document (web page) layout & tags used to create web pages
according to industry standards (e.g., header, footer, side bar, main content,
navigation/menu bar, tabs/drop downs).

Demonstrate ability to create a web site utilizing the latest version of HTML (e.g.,
headings, paragraphs, breaks, lists, links, images, horizontal rules, divs).

Demonstrate ability to format text using proper tags set by the W3C (strong,
emphasize).
Demonstrate ability to use tables to control the layout and appearance of data.
Demonstrate ability to create forms that accepts user inputs.

Demonstrate understanding of the importance of validating web sites and tools
available for the process.
Identify and use design and color principles appropriate for graphics and web pages.

Describe the image formats used within a web page (gif, jpg, png, image maps) and
describe appropriate use of which format.
Add images to a web page to enhance meaning of web content.

Explore online tools and downloadable software available to create and edit still and
animated graphics.

Use knowledge of how and why style sheets are used in web design to explain
design elements of a web site.

Create and modify internal and external style sheets to format the styling of text,
layout tables, content flow, positioning of objects.

Design web pages utilizing CSS to manage text flow using regions, columns, and
graphical interfaces.

Explain the differences between the types of editing software and when to editing
software: text, object, and WYSIWYG (What You See Is What You Get).
Create a website which implements tables.

Design web sites using a GUI-based editor following the design principles to enable
navigation, usability, and accessibility.

Explore advanced layouts & scripting tools available through GUI-based editors such
as widgets, image sliders, etc.
Create and use interactive forms on a web site.
Design and implement layers, image maps, and navigation bars.
Enhance a website with media objects and images.

Develop a working e-commerce vocabulary including e-business, mobile commerce,
branding, market space, business model (B2B, B2C), security, payment options.

Explain the importance of branding and establishing a color palette for an e-business
to create an online presence.
Explain the importance of using web design principles to meet customer expectations.

Explain the benefits of configuring a site to mobile standards currently used further
the accessibility of an e-business.

Identify essential issues in developing and maintaining a web site, including project
management, testing, legal issues.

Identify strategies commonly used for managing a user's experience and improving
site creativity and aesthetic qualities.
Explore options for publishing a web site and web hosting.

Identify the benefits and drawbacks of running your own web server versus using a
service provider.

Plan and deliver oral presentations of a web site explaining the developmental
process before, during, and after site completion to a potential customer.

Explore the historical significance and progression of web design/development
languages (e.g., HTML, CSS, HTML5, and JavaScript).
Distinguish between CSS and HTML.
Demonstrate knowledge of HTML5 elements.
Build a website using < div > tags rather than tables.

Evaluate various HTML and CSS frameworks (e.g., HTML5 boilerplate, Bootstrap,
Foundation or others).
Analyze pros and cons of using a HTML and CSS frameworks.
Demonstrate the difference between a class versus ID.
Apply selector, property, and value using HTML5.
Investigate the pros and cons of using inline styles.
Compare the pros and cons of pixels versus em.
Differentiate between margin and padding.
Apply appropriate positioning to items on a web page.

Evaluate compatibility issues for browsers/browser versions and demonstrate ways to
overcome those issues.
Understand scripting in JavaScript and how it applies to web page development.
Demonstrate how JavaScript can enhance a project.

Compare the pros and cons of using various JavaScript libraries (e.g., jQuery,
Prototype, MooTools).
Distinguish between variables and functions in writing JavaScript.

Explore different causes of JavaScript security, including Cross site scripting (XSS) and
the problems with using eval( ).
Create code from design mockup.
Generate HTML that incorporates major formatting tags as well as mixed media assets.

Utilize CSS to achieve different visual looks for a webpage without modifying the
underlying html.

Build a styled HTML page implementing a form that incorporates JavaScript checking
and interacts with the data provided.
Implement a third party JavaScript tool and explain how it works and what it does.

Write code that is compatible across a given set of web browsers and versions (most
notably Internet Explorer (IE), Chrome, Firefox, and Safari).
Demonstrate ability to apply security principles to HTML and JavaScript.

Evaluate the selection and use of software libraries in building client facing portions of
the webpage (e.g., HTML5 Boilerplate, Bootstrap, Foundation, jQuery, Angular).
Explain the role of the web server in the development stack.
Explain the role of the database in the development stack.
Explain the role of the server side language in the development stack.
Debate the appropriate web stack for a given problem set.

Demonstrate security mitigation techniques that can be addressed at each level of the
development stack.

Explore the history of common server side languages (e.g., Ruby On Rails, PHP or
others).
Explain the differences in server side languages in terms of syntax and function.

Debate the merits and use of software design patterns as it relates to a dynamic web
site.

Build a server script demonstrating language control structures and mathematical
computations.

Build a script demonstrating data storage using cookies, sessions, a database, and file
storage.

Write code to perform a file upload and validate the uploaded file against given
business rules.
Incorporate a third party library into a script and explain what it does and how it works.

Explain how a third party library was chosen if multiple libraries with the same purpose
are available.
Install and configure a Content Management Systems (CMS).

Demonstrate ability to apply security principles to Server Side Code as it relates to data
storage and display.
Explain at least one website attack vector and how to mitigate the risk of that attack.
Apply responsive design and development.

Understand search engine crawlers, such as Google, Bing, Yahoo!, and Baidu, in
regards to crawling, indexing and ranking of webpages.

Master and apply effective use of meta-tags in HTML head of each webpage of a site
(title tag, description tag, and keywords tag) and the URL file name.
Understand image optimization of .jpeg, .gif and .png (compressing, < img > html tag).
Plan and employ an internal link strategy of a site.

Research search engine algorithms, how frequently they are updated, and how they
impact a site’s ranking.
Comprehend and apply best practice techniques for keywords and keywords research.

Apply semantic markup to every page of a site (effectively using H1, H2, H3, paragraph,
and list tags).

Demonstrate how semantic markup impacts a site’s architecture, web coding, usability
and display flexibility.

Examine basic SEO tools such as Google Search Console (formerly Google
Webmaster Tools) Bing Webmaster Tools, and Google Analytics.

Explain the different steps of SDLC (Plan, Analyze, Design, Develop, and Implement
Maintain).

Research and describe the different types of collaboration platforms used in web
development (e.g., GITHub, Apache Subversion (SVN) or others).

Ensure websites meet all special considerations and are in compliance with
industry and government regulations.

Explain what encryption (https) is and under what circumstances it would be appropriate
to implement on a website.

Research and explain a specialized web compliance practice based on a governmental
or industry guideline - Payment Card Industry (PCI), Section 508, American Disability
Act (ADA), etc.
Explain how security could differ between an application on the internet vs. an intranet.

Determine the fault involved in a data breach and research types of protections
pertinent for a particular website.

Explore principles of e-commerce as they apply to web development, mobile devices,
banking, and government regulations.
